briefdescription.para: typedef to Traits::FT.
typedef to Traits::Point.
non-mutable model of the STL concept BidirectionalIterator with value type Point.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the points used to build the smallest enclosing sphere.

briefdescription.para: non-mutable model of the STL concept BidirectionalIterator with value type Point.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the support points defining the smallest enclosing sphere.

briefdescription.para: creates a variable of type Min_sphere_d and initializes it to $ ms(\emptyset)$.

detaileddescription.para: If the traits parameter is not supplied, the class Traits must provide a default constructor.

briefdescription.para: creates a variable min_sphere of type Min_sphere_d.

detaileddescription.para:
It is initialized to $ ms(P)$ with $ P$ being the set of points in the range [first,last).
InputIterator
is a model of InputIterator with Point as value type. If the traits parameter is not supplied, the class Traits must provide a default constructor.
All points have the same dimension.

briefdescription.para: returns the number of points of min_sphere, i.e. $ |P|$.
returns the number of support points of min_sphere, i.e. $ |S|$.
returns an iterator referring to the first point of min_sphere.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the first support point of min_sphere.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns the dimension of the points in $ P$.

detaileddescription.para: If min_sphere is empty, the ambient dimension is $ -1$.

briefdescription.para: returns the center of min_sphere.
returns the squared radius of min_sphere.

description.para: By definition, an empty Min_sphere_d has no boundary and no bounded side, i.e. its unbounded side equals the whole space $ \E^d$.

briefdescription.para: returns CGAL::ON_BOUNDED_SIDE, CGAL::ON_BOUNDARY, or CGAL::ON_UNBOUNDED_SIDE iff p lies properly inside, on the boundary, or properly outside of min_sphere, resp.

simplesect.para: If min_sphere is not empty, the dimension of $ p$ equals ambient_dimension().

briefdescription.para: returns true, iff p lies properly inside min_sphere.

simplesect.para: If min_sphere is not empty, the dimension of $ p$ equals ambient_dimension().

briefdescription.para: returns true, iff p lies on the boundary of min_sphere.

simplesect.para: if min_sphere is not empty, the dimension of $ p$ equals ambient_dimension().

briefdescription.para: returns true, iff p lies properly outside of min_sphere.

simplesect.para: If min_sphere is not empty, the dimension of $ p$ equals ambient_dimension().

briefdescription.para: returns true, iff min_sphere is empty (this implies degeneracy).
returns true, iff min_sphere is degenerate, i.e. if min_sphere is empty or equal to a single point, equivalently if the number of support points is less than 2.
resets min_sphere to $ ms(\emptyset)$.
sets min_sphere to the $ ms(P)$, where $ P$ is the set of points in the range [first,last).

parameterdescription.para: is a model of InputIterator with Point as value type.

simplesect.para: All points have the same dimension.

briefdescription.para: inserts p into min_sphere.

detaileddescription.para:
If p lies inside the current sphere, this is a constant-time operation, otherwise it might take longer, but usually substantially less than recomputing the smallest enclosing sphere from scratch.
The dimension of p equals ambient_dimension() if min_sphere is not empty.

briefdescription.para: inserts the points in the range [first,last) into min_sphere and recomputes the smallest enclosing sphere, by calling insert for all points in the range.

parameterdescription.para: is a model of InputIterator with Point as value type.

simplesect.para: All points have the same dimension. If min_sphere is not empty, this dimension must be equal to ambient_dimension().

description.para: An object min_sphere is valid, iff

listitem.para: min_sphere contains all points of its defining set $ P$,
min_sphere is the smallest sphere containing its support set $ S$, and
$ S$ is minimal, i.e. no support point is redundant.

simplesect.para: Under inexact arithmetic, the result of the validation is not realiable, because the checker itself can suffer from numerical problems.

briefdescription.para: returns true, iff min_sphere is valid.

detaileddescription.para: If verbose is true, some messages concerning the performed checks are written to standard error stream. The second parameter level is not used, we provide it only for consistency with interfaces of other classes.

briefdescription.para: returns a const reference to the traits class object.
writes min_sphere to output stream os.

detaileddescription.para: An overload of operator<< must be defined for Point.

briefdescription.para: reads min_sphere from input stream is.

detaileddescription.para: An overload of operator>> must be defined for Point

briefdescription.para: An object of the class Min_sphere_d is the unique sphere of smallest volume enclosing a finite (multi)set of points in $ d$-dimensional Euclidean space $ \E^d$.

detaileddescription.para: For a set $ P$ we denote by $ ms(P)$ the smallest sphere that contains all points of $ P$. $ ms(P)$ can be degenerate, i.e. $ ms(P)=\emptyset$ if $ P=\emptyset$ and $ ms(P)=\{p\}$ if $ P=\{p\}$.

An inclusion-minimal subset $ S$ of $ P$ with $ ms(S)=ms(P)$ is called a support set, the points in $ S$ are the support points. A support set has size at most $ d+1$, and all its points lie on the boundary of $ ms(P)$. In general, neither the support set nor its size are unique.
The algorithm computes a support set $ S$ which remains fixed until the next insert or clear operation.

Please note: This class is (almost) obsolete. The class CGAL::Min_sphere_of_spheres_d<Traits> solves a more general problem and is faster then Min_sphere_d even if used only for points as input. Most importantly, CGAL::Min_sphere_of_spheres_d<Traits> has a specialized implementation for floating-point arithmetic which ensures correct results in a large number of cases (including highly degenerate ones). In contrast, Min_sphere_d is not reliable under floating-point computations. The only advantage of Min_sphere_d over CGAL::Min_sphere_of_spheres_d<Traits> is that the former can deal with points in homogeneous coordinates, in which case the algorithm is division-free. Thus, Min_sphere_d might still be an option in case your input number type cannot (efficiently) divide.

Traits
must be a model of the concept OptimisationDTraits as its template argument.
We provide the models CGAL::Optimisation_d_traits_2, CGAL::Optimisation_d_traits_3 and CGAL::Optimisation_d_traits_d for two-, three-, and $ d$-dimensional points respectively.

We implement the algorithm of Welzl with move-to-front heuristic [16] for small point sets, combined with a new efficient method for large sets, which is particularly tuned for moderately large dimension ( $ d \leq 20$) [8]. The creation time is almost always linear in the number of points. Access functions and predicates take constant time, inserting a point might take up to linear time, but substantially less than computing the new smallest enclosing sphere from scratch. The clear operation and the check for validity each take linear time.
